docs.lead_paragraph: Culinary building blocks: This is the season for refresher courses in food history and refurbishing that time-battered batterie de cuisine. End-of-year dream excursions include yachts cruising the Greek islands in search of mountain greens and barley biscuits, and long-tailed boats navigating Mekong Delta canals seeking fragrant rice. Forget what you thought you knew about choosing and cooking perfect rice. And buy a sack of bread flour and look for a non-Zone New Year's diet: meat is prominent on the curriculum, but so are carbohydrates -- lovingly shaped by hand, of course. I had to restrain myself from scrawling ''must try'' beside yet another recipe in Aglaia Kremezi's FOODS OF THE GREEK ISLANDS: Cooking and Culture at the Crossroads of the Mediterranean (Houghton Mifflin, $35). I've had the good fortune to dine with the author at various conferences in her home country, but I had no idea of the riches that lay behind the stucco doorways of its houses -- or in the kitchens of its tavernas -- once the foreigners were gone.

headline.main: An Ailing Russia Lives a Tough Life That's Getting Shorter

docs.abstract: Life expectancy in Russia is falling, symptom of precipitous decline in country's public health and barometer of poverty, insecurity and stress plaguing its population; life expectancy for both men and women is average 65.9 years, about 10 years less than in United States; since 1990, death rate has risen almost one-third, to highest of any major nation, and birth rate has dropped almost 40 percent, making it among very lowest; maps and charts of birth and death rates, life expectancy and leading causes of death; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When the chest pains first gripped him that February day in 1998, Anatoly Iverianov was driving a tractor through one of the birch-and-pine forests that carpet Russia's border with Finland, dragging fresh-cut logs to a wood lot. ''I had a glass of vodka,'' he said. ''I thought that would help.''
